title: Bulgarian football fans' racism could easily have taken place in England
text:
Zero tolerance is not displaying a banner. It is not a photo opportunity. It’s not a stadium announcement (Picture: NIKOLAY DOYCHINOV/AFP via Getty Images)

I’m disappointed, disgusted… but in no way surprised by the racism displayed by the Bulgarian fans towards England in the Euro 2020 qualifier on Monday.

You can’t be shocked by racism in football anymore. It’s the norm. It’s ingrained in our favourite sport.

It was a matter of when, not if, a game would finally be stopped because of racism, whether it was in this country or on foreign shores.

The current UEFA protocols – that I presume are meant to protect players from any continued abuse, be it physical or verbal – have left me perplexed. I ask: do they really want to stamp racism out of the beautiful game?

Zero tolerance is not displaying a banner. It is not a photo opportunity. It’s not a stadium announcement.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The contempt shown by one man holding up a ‘No Respect’ hoodie shows you how much impact they have. It was essentially two fingers being held up to UEFA and what they currently have in place to try and deal with this.

What is a partial stadium closure? I’ll tell you what it means. It means the perpetrators get to sit in a different seat or another section of the ground.

Everyone is now demanding stronger actions, but who are we demanding that from? An organisation that stutters and bumbles its way through every time the issue of racism arises.

It’s time to get tough. That includes tournament expulsions and points deductions.

There is much more work needed from UEFA. They have to shake off this lazy attitude every time racism lands at their door.

We shouldn’t let what happened in Bulgaria distract from what needs to be done back home (Picture: Reuters/Carl Recine)

Gareth Southgate said, rightly, his players have become ‘hardened’ to racial abuse because of experiences in their own country. And let’s not for one minute forget the very same abuse continues to flourish in England.

Advertisement

Advertisement

We shouldn’t let what happened in Bulgaria distract from what needs to be done back home. It could just as easily have happened in England. Yes, it could. Maybe in a different shape or form, but it could.

At Kick It Out we receive reports of discrimination from all levels of the English game week in, week out. It’s happening everywhere, from your local Sunday league pitches to the Premier League.

We need to face up to our own responsibilities in dealing with racism. And we all have a duty.

The burden should not be on players and managers to remove themselves from the pitch (Picture: Reuters/Carl Recine)

We must challenge hatred whenever we encounter it. We must be together on these issues or else what’s the point? We must have faith that culprits will be dealt with appropriately.

Nobody should ever have to encounter abuse and just ‘get on with it’. That’s why the three-step protocol exists. So, either use it or don’t question players if they take matters into their own hands because you have failed to protect them.

To quote Gareth Southgate, the protocol offers ‘clarity and protection’ to players. But it doesn’t when it’s only partly enforced.

The burden should not be on players and managers to remove themselves from the pitch. They should be able to trust the officials to do their jobs properly.

Advertisement

If the UEFA officials had done that last night, we may have seen the match abandoned. So when people say to me was last night was progress, I say they just teased us into thinking they were doing the right thing.

And that just isn’t cutting it anymore.
